text: SOP No. 14
label: BODY

text: Recommended Standard Operating Procedure
label: HH1

text: for
label: BODY

text: Gravimetric Calibration of Volumetric Standards Using an Electronic Balance
label: BODY

text: Introduction
label: BODY

text: Purpose of Test
label: BODY

text: This procedure is a precision mass calibration converting mass values to
label: BODY

text: volumetric values using pure water as a standard reference material. The results
label: BODY

text: provide calibration of either the "to deliver" or "to contain" volume of measuring
label: BODY

text: containers that may be used as volumetric measuring standards. The procedure
label: BODY

text: uses gravimetric calibration principles to minimize calibration uncertainties.
label: BODY

text: Accordingly, the procedure is especially useful for high accuracy calibrations.
label: BODY

text: The procedure references measurement control standards to ensure the validity of
label: BODY

text: the standards and the measurement process; however, additional good
label: BODY

text: measurement practices such as those required for precision mass calibrations must
label: BODY

text: be used. The procedure makes use of an electronic balance and is suitable for all
label: BODY

text: sizes of gravimetric calibrations only limited by the capacity and resolution of the
label: BODY

text: balance and handling capabilities. Standards that are calibrated for use in legal
label: BODY

text: weights and measures applications should be evaluated for conformance to the
label: BODY

text: appropriate specifications and tolerances that apply. This procedure calculates the
label: BODY

text: average volume based on two runs. NOTE: NIST calibrations generally make use
label: BODY

text: of the average of five replicates.
label: BODY

text: Prerequisites
label: BODY

text: 1.2.1 Verify that valid calibration certificates with appropriate values and
label: BODY

text: uncertainties are available for all of the standards used in the calibration.
label: BODY

text: All standards must have demonstrated metrological traceability to the
label: BODY

text: international system of units (SI), which may be to the SI through a
label: BODY

text: National Metrology Institute such as NIST.
label: BODY

text: 1.2.2 Verify that the mass standards to be used have sufficiently small standard
label: BODY

text: uncertainties for the level of calibration. Reference mass standards should
label: BODY

text: not be used for gravimetric calibration due to the risk of water
label: BODY

text: contamination. Weights of ASTM Class 2 or 3 or OIML Class F1 or F2 are
label: BODY

text: recommended for this procedure. Working standards of other classes are
label: BODY

text: generally not designed to maintain adequate stability needed; however,
label: BODY

text: corrections obtained within a few days of the volume calibration may
label: BODY

text: provide adequate stability and may be used if the uncertainty is
label: BODY

text: sufficiently small and the density is available for performing buoyancy
label: BODY

text: corrections.
label: BODY

text: January 2016
label: BODY

text: SOP 14
label: BODY

text: Page 2 of 19
label: BODY

text: 1.2.3 Verify that the balance used is in good operating condition with adequate
label: BODY

text: capacity, sufficiently small resolution, and sufficiently small process
label: BODY

text: standard deviation, as verified by a valid control chart or preliminary
label: BODY

text: experiments using this procedure. NOTE:  standard deviations obtained
label: BODY

text: from mass calibrations do not reflect the process repeatability of
label: BODY

text: gravimetric calibrations; therefore process repeatability must be obtained
label: BODY

text: using this procedure! The accuracy of the balance and weighing
label: BODY

text: procedures should be evaluated to minimize potential bias in the
label: BODY

text: measurement process.
label: BODY

text: 1.2.4 Verify that the operator is experienced in precision weighing techniques
label: BODY

text: and has had specific training in SOP 2, SOP 4, SOP 29, GMP 3, GMP 10,
label: BODY

text: and gravimetric calibrations.
label: BODY

text: 1.2.5 Verify that an adequate quality and supply of distilled or deionized water
label: BODY

text: (see GLP 10) is available. Note: Do not use tap water for this procedure!
label: BODY

text: 1.2.6 Verify that air currents are minimized in the laboratory when weighing is
label: BODY

text: performed. Verify that the laboratory facilities meet the following
label: BODY

text: minimum conditions to enable meeting the expected uncertainty that is
label: BODY

text: achievable with this procedure:
label: BODY

text: Table 1.  Laboratory environmental conditions.
label: HH1

text: Procedure
label: BODY

text: Temperature
label: BODY

text: Relative Humidity
label: BODY

text: Gravimetric
label: BODY

text: 20 C to 23 C
label: BODY

text: Stable to ± 1 C / 1 h, during the calibration

text: Methodology
label: BODY

text: Scope, Precision, Accuracy
label: BODY

text: The procedure is applicable for the calibration of any size of measuring container
label: BODY

text: that, when filled with water, will not overload the electronic balance used.
label: BODY

text: Typical containers range in capacity from 1 mL to 20 L; however, this procedure
label: BODY

text: is also applicable for larger provers provided that facility, equipment and
label: BODY

text: standards meet the requirements in this SOP. When larger provers (e.g., 100 gal
label: BODY

text: or more) are tested, also see the Test Notes in the Appendix. The procedure is
label: BODY

text: generally only appropriate for micropipettes when additional evaporation
label: BODY

text: corrections are made. The precision of calibration depends on the care exercised
label: BODY

text: in adjusting the various volumes and strict adherence to the various steps of the
label: BODY

text: procedure. The accuracy attainable depends on the ability of the operator to read
label: BODY

text: and set the meniscus, uncertainties of the standard weights, the air buoyancy
label: BODY

text: corrections, and thermal expansion corrections that are made.
label: BODY

text: January 2016
label: BODY

text: SOP 14
label: BODY

text: Page 3 of 19
label: BODY

text: Summary
label: BODY

text: The electronic balance used is calibrated by incorporating standard masses into
label: BODY

text: the procedure. The volumetric vessel to be calibrated is then weighed dry or
label: BODY

text: “wetted down,” depending on whether the calibration is to be made on a “To
label: BODY

text: Contain” or “To Deliver” basis. The container is filled with pure water of known
label: BODY

text: temperature and re-weighed. The difference in mass is used to calculate the
label: BODY

text: capacity of the container at the nominal capacity and at various capacities when
label: BODY

text: multiple neck graduations are present. Transfer vessels may be used for all
label: BODY

text: procedures except for flasks and containers marked “To Contain” (TC).
label: BODY

text: Standards and Equipment Requirements
label: BODY

text: 2.3.1 An electronic balance having sufficient capacity to weigh the loaded
label: BODY

text: vessel is required. The balance selection affects the potential measurement
label: BODY

text: errors associated with this procedure. Prior to use and where available, it
label: BODY

text: is recommended to use the adjust/calibrate feature on balances. Option A
label: BODY

text: provides a single point calibration factor for the balance. In general,
label: BODY

text: concerns are greater for balances or mass comparators larger than 5 kg due
label: BODY

text: to corner loading errors, non-linearity, and repeatability over the range of
label: BODY

text: use. Option B as described in the calculation section for larger volumes
label: BODY

text: corrects for balance non-linearity in both the filled and empty/drained
label: BODY

text: ranges of use. Option B will also likely be required on mass comparators
label: BODY

text: that have multiple ranges. It also provides corrections for variations in air
label: BODY

text: density that may occur over a longer weighing process on larger volumes.
label: BODY

text: For all procedures in this SOP, the balance should be zeroed prior to each
label: BODY

text: measurement to minimize possible effects due to balance drift. The
label: BODY

text: sensitivity or resolution of the balance may be a limiting factor in the
label: BODY

text: accuracy of the measurement. The resolution and repeatability must be
label: BODY

text: smaller than the accepted uncertainty of the calibration. Linearity errors or
label: BODY

text: additional uncertainties may need to be considered when the mass
label: BODY

text: standards are slightly less than the volume or container being measured.
label: BODY

text: 2.3.2 Sufficient quantity of calibrated mass standards. Mass standards are
label: BODY

text: selected so that they are slightly larger than the combined mass of the
label: BODY

text: volume and container or transfer vessel that will be weighed. When
label: BODY

text: summations of masses are used, the summation mass is used, and the
label: BODY

text: “effective density” must be calculated, taking care not to use “average”
label: BODY

text: density values.
label: BODY

text: 2.3.3 Thermometer with resolution and uncertainty less than 0.1 °C to
label: BODY

text: determine water temperature.
label: BODY

text: 2.3.4 Thermometer with resolution and uncertainty less than 0.50 °C to
label: BODY

text: determine air temperature. 1
label: BODY

text: January 2016
label: BODY

text: SOP 14
label: BODY

text: Page 4 of 19
label: BODY

text: 2.3.5 Barometer with resolution and uncertainty less than 135 Pa (1 mm Hg) to
label: BODY

text: determine air pressure.1
label: BODY

text: 2.3.6 Hygrometer with resolution and uncertainty less than 10  % to determine
label: BODY

text: relative humidity.1
label: BODY

text: 2.3.7 Distilled or deionized water (See GLP 10) of sufficient quality and
label: BODY

text: quantity for the calibration. Note: Do not use tap water for this procedure!
label: BODY

text: 2.3.8 Stopwatch or other suitable timing device (does not need to be calibrated.)
label: BODY

text: General Considerations
label: BODY

text: 2.4.1 Cleanliness checks
label: BODY

text: Verify that all containers to be calibrated are clean as evidenced by
label: BODY

text: uniform drainage of water. No water droplets should remain on any
label: BODY

text: interior surface as the water drains from the container. A reproducible
label: BODY

text: “wet-down” weight is evidence for cleanliness in cases where it is not
label: BODY

text: possible to visually check for uniform drainage. Use GMP 6 or 7 to clean
label: BODY

text: vessels as necessary. All glassware must be meticulously cleaned, prior to
label: BODY

text: calibration. When clean, the walls will be uniformly wetted. Instructions
label: BODY

text: for cleaning are given in GMP 6 and GMP 7. An exception is plastic ware,
label: BODY

text: which will not be wetted. Follow manufacturer's instructions for cleaning
label: BODY

text: such vessels. Do not use cleaning agents that will attack, discolor, or swell
label: BODY

text: plastic ware.
label: BODY

text: 2.4.2 Use water that is thermally equilibrated with the laboratory environment.
label: BODY

text: Equilibration can be achieved by storing the water in clean containers in
label: BODY

text: the laboratory. It is important to use water that is equilibrated in the
label: BODY

text: laboratory as much as possible to minimize potential calibration errors and
label: BODY

text: convection currents during the calibration. Consider water to be
label: BODY

text: equilibrated when within ± 5 °C of the laboratory temperature.
label: BODY

text: 2.4.3 Volumetric calibrations to a marked volume (graduation line) are critically
label: BODY

text: dependent on the setting of a meniscus. See GMP 3 for guidance in
label: BODY

text: reading a meniscus.
label: BODY

text: 2.4.4 Use GLP 13 as the procedure to dry any container to be calibrated on a
label: BODY

text: “To Contain” basis.
label: BODY

text: 2.4.5 Wet down (not used for any container calibrated “To Contain”)
label: BODY

text: For glassware and hand-held test measures: Fill the container to capacity
label: BODY

text: with distilled or deionized water, then empty over a 30 s period while
label: BODY

text: avoiding splashing. Drain for 10 s unless another drain time is specified.
label: BODY

text: January 2016
label: BODY

text: SOP 14
label: BODY

text: Page 5 of 19
label: BODY

text: (This is commonly called a “30 s pour, 10 s drain” emptying procedure.)
label: BODY

text: A 30 s (± 5 s) pour followed by a 10 s drain, with the measure held
label: BODY

text: between a 10 degree and 15 degree angle from vertical is required during
label: BODY

text: calibration and use for glass flasks. A wet-down is not required for a
label: BODY

text: transfer vessel that is used to weigh a delivered volume of water.
label: BODY

text: For stationary provers: Fill the container to capacity with distilled or
label: BODY

text: deionized water, then empty. Time the drain once the cessation of the
label: BODY

text: main flow is complete for 30 s and close the valve.
label: BODY

text: Calibration Procedure for Burets
label: BODY

text: 2.5.1 Clamp the buret vertically on a support stand. Also clamp a plain glass test
label: BODY

text: tube or beaker, large enough to hold a thermometer, in the vicinity of the
label: BODY

text: buret.
label: BODY

text: 2.5.2 Fill the buret with water and test for absence of leaks from the tip and
label: BODY

text: stopcock. Drain and fill several times to condition the buret. Fill when
label: BODY

text: ready to test.
label: BODY

text: 2.5.3 Drain and record the delivery time, defined as the time of unrestricted
label: BODY

text: flow from the zero mark to the lowest graduation mark with the stopcock
label: BODY

text: fully open.
label: BODY

text: 2.5.4 Fill the buret slightly above the zero mark with temperature-equilibrated
label: BODY

text: water and also fill the test tube that holds the thermometer. Record the
label: BODY

text: water temperature.
label: BODY

text: 2.5.5 Set the meniscus on the zero mark and touch the tip with the wetted wall
label: BODY

text: of a beaker to remove any excess water. The buret tip must be full.
label: BODY

text: 2.5.6 Measure and record the air temperature, air pressure, and relative
label: BODY

text: humidity.
label: BODY

text: 2.5.7 Zero the balance and then place a known mass standard on the balance pan
label: BODY

text: that is slightly larger than the filled capacity of the empty transfer vessel
label: BODY

text: or flask when filled with water. Record the reading as O1.
label: BODY

text: 2.5.8 Zero the balance and then weigh an empty transfer vessel or flask
label: BODY

text: including the stopper or cover to be used. Record as O2.
label: BODY

text: 2.5.9 Fully open the stopcock and discharge the contents of the buret into the
label: BODY

text: previously weighed flask or transfer vessel. The tip of the buret should be
label: BODY

text: in contact with the wall of the flask. When the level in the buret is within a
label: BODY

text: few millimeters above the line being calibrated, slow the discharge and
label: BODY

text: January 2016
label: BODY

text: SOP 14
label: BODY

text: Page 6 of 19
label: BODY

text: make an accurate setting. When the setting is completed, move the flask
label: BODY

text: horizontally to break contact with the tip. Recheck the setting.
label: BODY

text: 2.5.10 Stopper (or cover) the filled transfer vessel or flask. Check to make sure
label: BODY

text: that the outside of the transfer vessel or flask is not wet. Zero the balance
label: BODY

text: and then weigh the filled transfer vessel or flask. Record the balance
label: BODY

text: reading as O3.
label: BODY

text: 2.5.11 Measure and record the temperature of water in the container.
label: BODY

text: 2.5.12 Test the next interval in the same manner - from the zero mark to the next
label: BODY

text: interval of test.
label: BODY

text: 2.5.13 For burets with a specified waiting time, empty as in 2.5.9 to within a few
label: BODY

text: millimeters of the calibration mark. Pause for the specified waiting time
label: BODY

text: (e.g., 10 s), then adjust the meniscus to the graduation line as in 2.5.9.
label: BODY

text: 2.5.14 Measure and record the air temperature, air pressure, and relative
label: BODY

text: humidity.
label: BODY

text: 2.5.15 Make a duplicate determination for each interval (Run 2).
label: BODY

text: 2.5.16 Calculate the volume for each interval as described in Section 3, Option
label: BODY

text: Calibration Procedure for Pipets (One-Mark)
label: BODY

text: 2.6.1 Measure and record the air temperature, air pressure, and relative
label: BODY

text: humidity.
label: BODY

text: 2.6.2 Zero the balance and then place a known mass standard on the balance pan
label: BODY

text: that is slightly larger than the filled capacity of the empty transfer vessel
label: BODY

text: or flask when filled with water. Record the reading as O1.
label: BODY

text: 2.6.3 Zero the balance and then weigh an empty transfer vessel or flask,
label: BODY

text: including the stopper or cover that will be used. Record the balance
label: BODY

text: reading as O2.
label: BODY

text: 2.6.4 Fill the pipet to the index mark and measure the delivery time with the tip
label: BODY

text: in contact with the internal surface of a beaker (not the transfer vessel that
label: BODY

text: will be used.)
label: BODY

text: 2.6.5 Refill the pipet by suction, slightly above the index line. Record the water
label: BODY

text: temperature. Wipe tip with filter paper, then slowly lower level to the
label: BODY

text: index line, using a stopcock or pinch clamp for fine control. The tip must
label: BODY

text: January 2016
label: BODY

text: SOP 14
label: BODY

text: Page 7 of 19
label: BODY

text: be in contact with the wetted wall of the beaker while this setting is being
label: BODY

text: made. Do not remove any water remaining on tip at this time.
label: BODY

text: 2.6.6 Hold the pipet in a vertical position and deliver water into the previously
label: BODY

text: weighed transfer vessel or flask, with the tip in contact with the inside
label: BODY

text: wall or neck.
label: BODY

text: 2.6.7 After flow has ceased, wait two seconds then remove the pipet from
label: BODY

text: contact with the flask. Check to make sure that the outside of the transfer
label: BODY

text: vessel or flask is not wet.
label: BODY

text: 2.6.8 Stopper (or cover) the filled transfer vessel or flask. Zero the balance and
label: BODY

text: then weigh the transfer vessel or flask. Record the balance reading as O3.
label: BODY

text: 2.6.9 Measure and record the temperature of water in the container.
label: BODY

text: 2.6.10 Measure and record the air temperature, air pressure, and relative
label: BODY

text: humidity.
label: BODY

text: 2.6.11 Make a duplicate determination for the pipet (Run 2).
label: BODY

text: 2.6.12 Calculate the volume as described in Section 3, Option A.
label: BODY

text: Calibration of Flasks (To Contain) – Transfer vessel must not be used.
label: BODY

text: 2.7.1 Clean and dry the flask to be calibrated as described in GLP 13. Then
label: BODY

text: stopper the flask.
label: BODY

text: 2.7.2 Measure and record the air temperature, air pressure, and relative
label: BODY

text: humidity.
label: BODY

text: 2.7.3 Zero the balance and then place a known mass standard on the balance pan
label: BODY

text: that is slightly larger than the filled capacity of the flask when filled with
label: BODY

text: water. Record the reading as O1.
label: BODY

text: 2.7.4 Zero the balance and then weigh the dry flask including its stopper or
label: BODY

text: cover. Record the balance reading as O2.
label: BODY

text: 2.7.5 Place an appropriate sized funnel in neck and fill the flask to just below
label: BODY

text: the reference graduation while maneuvering the flask to wet the entire
label: BODY

text: neck below the stopper. Let stand for two minutes then adjust the
label: BODY

text: meniscus to the reference graduation line, taking care to avoid wetting the
label: BODY

text: neck above the capacity graduation.
label: BODY

text: 2.7.6 Check that the outside surface of the flask, and its internal surface above
label: BODY

text: the water level are dry, and that neither bubbles or foam are present in the
label: BODY

text: water. Remove visible water droplets if needed with a laboratory wipe.
label: BODY

text: January 2016
label: BODY

text: SOP 14
label: BODY

text: Page 8 of 19
label: BODY

text: Stopper or cover the flask.
label: BODY

text: 2.7.7 Zero the balance and then weigh the filled flask and its stopper or cover,
label: BODY

text: and record the balance reading as O3.
label: BODY

text: 2.7.8 Measure and record the temperature of the water in the flask or other
label: BODY

text: container.
label: BODY

text: 2.7.9 Measure and record the air temperature, air pressure, and relative
label: BODY

text: humidity.
label: BODY

text: 2.7.10 Make a duplicate determination (Run 2) after drying the flask per GLP 13.
label: BODY

text: 2.7.11 Perform volume calculations as described in Section 3, Option A.
label: BODY

text: Calibration of Flasks (To Deliver)
label: BODY

text: 2.8.1 Clean but do not dry the flask to be calibrated. Condition the flask by
label: BODY

text: filling and emptying the flask over a 30 s period by gradually inclining it
label: BODY

text: to avoid splashing. When the main flow has ceased, hold the flask in a
label: BODY

text: nearly vertical position for 10 seconds unless another drain time is
label: BODY

text: specified, then touch off the drop of water adhering to the tip of the flask.
label: BODY

text: 2.8.2 Measure and record the air temperature, air pressure, and relative
label: BODY

text: humidity.
label: BODY

text: 2.8.3 Zero the balance and then place a known mass standard on the balance pan
label: BODY

text: that is slightly larger than the filled capacity of the flask when filled with
label: BODY

text: water. Record the reading as O1.
label: BODY

text: 2.8.4 Zero the balance and then weigh the drained (empty) flask including its
label: BODY

text: stopper or cover. Record the balance reading as O2.
label: BODY

text: 2.8.5 Fill the flask to just below the reference graduation. Let the flask stand for
label: BODY

text: two minutes, then adjust the meniscus to the reference graduation line. Do
label: BODY

text: not dry the inside of the flask above the graduation line, but take care to
label: BODY

text: ensure that the outside of the flask is dry.
label: BODY

text: 2.8.6 Zero the balance and then weigh the filled vessel, with cap or stopper.
label: BODY

text: Record the balance reading as O3.
label: BODY

text: 2.8.7 Measure and record the temperature of the water in the flask.
label: BODY

text: 2.8.8 Measure and record the air temperature, air pressure, and relative
label: BODY

text: humidity.
label: BODY

text: January 2016
label: BODY

text: SOP 14
label: BODY

text: Page 9 of 19
label: BODY

text: 2.8.9 Make a duplicate determination (Run 2).
label: BODY

text: 2.8.10 Calculate the volume of the flask as described in Section 3, Option A.
label: BODY

text: Note: The order of weighing the filled and drained flask in Section 2.8 may be reversed. In that
label: BODY

text: case, the filled vessel is still weighed and recorded as O3, the flask is drained as in 2.8.1, and the
label: BODY

text: properly drained vessel is weighed and recorded as O2.
label: BODY

text: Calibration of Other Volumetric Glassware
label: BODY

text: 2.9.1 Measuring Pipets (non-single-mark) – Calibrate in a manner similar to that
label: BODY

text: used to calibrate burets (2.5).
label: BODY

text: 2.9.2 Graduated Cylinders – Calibrate in a manner similar to that used for flasks
label: BODY

text: (To Deliver cylinders, use section 2.8; To Contain cylinders, use section
label: BODY

text: Calibration of Slicker-Plate Type Standards
label: BODY

text: 2.10.1 This calibration makes use of Option B where equivalent mass standards
label: BODY

text: are used at both the filled and empty loads on the balance. A transfer
label: BODY

text: vessel is recommended.
label: BODY

text: 2.10.2 Condition the slicker-plate type standards with several wet-down runs to
label: BODY

text: fully ensure wet down and smooth valve operation.
label: BODY

text: 2.10.3 Measure and record the air temperature, air pressure, and relative
label: BODY

text: humidity.
label: BODY

text: 2.10.4 Zero the balance and then place a standard mass, MS1, on the balance
label: BODY

text: platform (MS1 should be slightly larger than the mass of the drained
label: BODY

text: vessel, dry vessel, or empty transfer vessel.)  Record reading as O1.
label: BODY

text: 2.10.5 Zero the balance. Place the dry or “wet-down” transfer vessel on the
label: BODY

text: balance platform, as appropriate, and record reading as O2. Caution:  all
label: BODY

text: containers must be dry on the outside for all weighing.
label: BODY

text: 2.10.6 Fill the slicker-plate standard to just above the rim of the standard. Record
label: BODY

text: the water temperature. Slide the slicker plate across the level top. Set the
label: BODY

text: transfer vessel below the nozzle to ensure all volume is transferred into the
label: BODY

text: vessel and that no splashing occurs.
label: BODY

text: 2.10.7 Open the slicker-plate standard valve and remove the plate simultaneously
label: BODY

text: and smoothly to deliver the water into the transfer vessel. Time the drain
label: BODY

text: for 30 s after cessation of the main flow and close the valve. Cover the
label: BODY

text: transfer vessel and move it from beneath the standard to ensure additional
label: BODY

text: January 2016
label: BODY

text: SOP 14
label: BODY

text: Page 10 of 19
label: BODY

text: drops of water are not transferred. Note: never fill the transfer vessel while
label: BODY

text: it is sitting on the balance platform to ensure that the balance is not
label: BODY

text: damaged with water and to avoid errors associated with balance drift and
label: BODY

text: hysteresis.
label: BODY

text: 2.10.8 Zero the balance and then place a standard mass, MS2, on the balance
label: BODY

text: platform (MS2 should be slightly larger than the mass of the filled vessel.)
label: BODY

text: Record the balance reading as O3.
label: BODY

text: 2.10.9 Zero the balance and then weigh the filled transfer vessel and record the
label: BODY

text: balance reading as O4.
label: BODY

text: 2.10.10 Immediately after weighing, check the temperature of the water in the
label: BODY

text: filled container. Ensure that the water has not changed by more than
label: BODY

text: 0.2 °C during the measurement process or repeat the run.
label: BODY

text: 2.10.11 Measure and record the air temperature, barometric pressure, and relative
label: BODY

text: humidity.
label: BODY

text: 2.10.12 Make a duplicate determination (Run 2).
label: BODY

text: 2.10.13 Calculate the volume as described in Section 3, Option B.
label: BODY

text: Calibration of Hand-held Graduated Neck Type Provers
label: BODY

text: 2.11.1 A hand-held test measure is weighed empty and filled much like the
label: BODY

text: procedure for To Deliver flasks (section 2.8). However, this calibration
label: BODY

text: makes use of Option B where equivalent mass standards are used at both
label: BODY

text: the filled and empty loads on the balance.
label: BODY

text: 2.11.2 Condition the test measure by filling and draining using a 30 s pour
label: BODY

text: followed by a 10 s drain. Take care to avoid splashing of water on the
label: BODY

text: outside of the measure. The wet-down will help equilibrate the test
label: BODY

text: measure with the water temperature.
label: BODY

text: 2.11.3 Measure and record the air temperature, air pressure, and relative
label: BODY

text: humidity.
label: BODY

text: 2.11.4 Zero the balance and then place standard masses, MS1, on the balance
label: BODY

text: platform (MS1 should be slightly larger than the mass of the drained
label: BODY

text: vessel.)  Record reading as O1.
label: BODY

text: 2.11.5 Zero the balance and then place the “wet-down” test measure on the
label: BODY

text: balance platform, and record the balance reading as O2. Caution:  all
label: BODY

text: containers must be dry on the outside for all weighing.
label: BODY

text: January 2016
label: BODY

text: SOP 14
label: BODY

text: Page 11 of 19
label: BODY

text: 2.11.6 Fill the graduated neck type test measure to just below the nominal
label: BODY

text: volume mark. Record the water temperature. Adjust the meniscus to
label: BODY

text: nominal.
label: BODY

text: 2.11.7 Zero the balance and then place standard masses, MS2, on the balance
label: BODY

text: platform (MS2 should be slightly larger than the mass of the filled vessel.)
label: BODY

text: Record the balance reading as O3.
label: BODY

text: 2.11.8 Zero the balance and then weigh the filled transfer vessel and record the
label: BODY

text: balance reading as O4.
label: BODY

text: 2.11.9 Immediately after weighing, check the temperature of the water in the
label: BODY

text: filled container. Ensure that the water has not changed by more than
label: BODY

text: 0.2 °C since step 2.11.6 or repeat the run.
label: BODY

text: 2.11.10 Measure and record the air temperature, barometric pressure, and relative
label: BODY

text: humidity.
label: BODY

text: 2.11.11 Make a duplicate determination (Run 2).
label: BODY

text: 2.11.12 Calculate the volume as described in Section 3, Option B. You may use
label: BODY

text: the average water temperature in calculations. If a neck scale plate
label: BODY

text: verification is performed, additional weighings may be performed after
label: BODY

text: setting the meniscus at each level.
label: BODY

text: Calibration of Large Volume Graduated Neck Type Provers
label: BODY

text: 2.12.1 This calibration makes use of Option B where approximately equivalent
label: BODY

text: mass standards are used at both the filled and empty loads on the balance.
label: BODY

text: A transfer vessel is recommended. The unknown vessel to be calibrated
label: BODY

text: must be elevated to facilitate transfer of water into the transfer vessel.
label: BODY

text: 2.12.2 Condition the prover with a wet-down run to fully ensure smooth valve
label: BODY

text: operation, temperature equilibration, and wet-down of the delivery system.
label: BODY

text: 2.12.3 Measure and record the air temperature, air pressure, and relative
label: BODY

text: humidity.
label: BODY

text: 2.12.4 Zero the balance and then place standard masses, MS1, on the balance
label: BODY

text: platform (MS1 should be slightly larger than the mass of the drained
label: BODY

text: vessel, dry vessel, or empty transfer vessel.)  Record reading as O1.
label: BODY

text: 2.12.5 Zero the balance. Place dry or “wet-down” transfer vessel including cover
label: BODY

text: on balance platform, as appropriate, and record reading as O2. Caution:
label: BODY

text: all containers must be dry on the outside for all weighing.
label: BODY

text: January 2016
label: BODY

text: SOP 14
label: BODY

text: Page 12 of 19
label: BODY

text: 2.12.6 Fill the graduated neck type prover to just below the nominal volume
label: BODY

text: mark. Record the water temperature. Adjust the meniscus to nominal. Set
label: BODY

text: the transfer vessel below the nozzle to ensure all volume is transferred into
label: BODY

text: the vessel and that no splashing occurs. Use hoses and piping of minimum
label: BODY

text: length to avoid errors associated with retention during delivery. Hoses
label: BODY

text: should be translucent so that cessation of the main flow is visible. Care
label: BODY

text: should be taken to ensure that there are no loops or sags in the hose that
label: BODY

text: may hold water. When using hoses or piping, be sure to include them as
label: BODY

text: part of the wet-down process.
label: BODY

text: 2.12.7 Open the unknown prover valve to deliver the water into the transfer
label: BODY

text: vessel. Time the drain for 30 s after the cessation of the main flow and
label: BODY

text: close the valve. Cover the transfer vessel and move it from beneath the
label: BODY

text: prover to ensure additional drops of water are not transferred.
label: BODY

text: 2.12.8 Zero the balance and then place standard masses, MS2, on the balance
label: BODY

text: platform (MS2 should be slightly larger than the mass of the filled vessel.)
label: BODY

text: Record the balance reading as O3.
label: BODY

text: 2.12.9 Zero the balance and then weigh the filled transfer vessel and its cover.
label: BODY

text: Record the balance reading as O4.
label: BODY

text: 2.12.10 Immediately after weighing, check the temperature of the water in the
label: BODY

text: filled container. The temperature should not change by more than 0.2 °C if
label: BODY

text: the prover and water have been equilibrated in the laboratory
label: BODY

text: environment.
label: BODY

text: 2.12.11 Measure and record the air temperature, barometric pressure, and relative
label: BODY

text: humidity.
label: BODY

text: 2.12.12 Make a duplicate determination (Run 2).
label: BODY

text: 2.12.13 Calculate the volume as described in Section 3, Option B. You may use
label: BODY

text: the average water temperatures for calculations.
label: BODY

text: Calculations
label: BODY

text: Option A – One-point balance calibration. Compute the volume at the
label: BODY

text: temperature under test, Vt, for each determination using the equation:
label: BODY

text: Eqn. 3.1
label: BODY

text: January 2016
label: BODY

text: SOP 14
label: BODY

text: Page 13 of 19
label: BODY

text: Note: the O3 value is the filled volume container or transfer vessel and O2 is the
label: BODY

text: dry, empty, or drained value. If the order of any weighing operations were
label: BODY

text: changed, the calculated volume may indicate a negative value.
label: BODY

text: Option B – Two point balance calibration. Compute the volume, Vt, for each
label: BODY

text: determination using the equation:

label: BODY

text: on whether O2 represents a dry or a “wet down” container at the
label: BODY

text: temperature of the measurement) (cm3 or mL)
label: BODY

text: Glassware is typically calibrated to 20 °C. Compute V20, the volume at 20 C, for
label: BODY

text: each run, using the expression:

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: volume at 60 F, for each run, using the expression (taking care to use the cubical
label: BODY

text: coefficient of expansion in °F-1):

label: BODY

text: Other Reference temperatures may be used. Common reference temperatures for
label: BODY

text: other liquids follow:
label: BODY

text: Commodity
label: BODY

text: Reference
label: BODY

text: Temperature
label: BODY

text: Frozen food labeled by volume (e.g., fruit juice)
label: BODY

text: -18 ºC (0 ºF)
label: BODY

text: Beer
label: BODY

text: Food that must be kept refrigerated (e.g., milk)
label: BODY

text: Distilled spirits or petroleum
label: BODY

text: Petroleum (International Reference)
label: BODY

text: 15 ºC (59 ºF)
label: BODY

text: Compressed Natural Gas (CNG)
label: BODY

text: Wine
label: BODY

text: 20 ºC (68 ºF)
label: BODY

text: Unrefrigerated liquids (e.g., sold unchilled, like soft drinks)
label: BODY

text: 20 ºC (68 ºF)
label: BODY

text: Hydrogen (H2)
label: BODY

text: 21 ºC (70 ºF)
label: BODY

text: Petroleum (Hawaii)
label: BODY

text: Calculate and report the mean volume of the volumetric standard at its applicable
label: BODY

text: reference temperature.
label: BODY

text: If adjustments were made during replicate runs, report the “as found” volume or
label: BODY

text: the mean of “as found” volumes and also the “as left” volume or mean of “as left”
label: BODY

text: volumes, as applicable, at the appropriate reference temperature. (I.e., do not
label: BODY

text: calculate a mean value by combining “as found” and “as left” values when
label: BODY

text: adjustments are made.)
label: BODY

text: Measurement Assurance
label: BODY

text: Duplicate the process with a suitable check standard (See GLP 1, SOP 30, in
label: BODY

text: NISTIR 6969, or Sec. 7.4, in NBS Handbook 145) or conduct replicate
label: BODY

text: measurements per SOP 17 or 20. Average values of the range or standard
label: BODY

text: deviation of similarly sized flasks or volumetric standards may be tracked on a
label: BODY

text: single range chart or standard deviation chart according to SOP 17 or 20. For
label: BODY

text: standards that may be and are adjusted, do not combine an “as found” value with
label: BODY

text: an “as left” value for the two runs entered into the chart; use the adjusted value
label: BODY

text: from Run 1 and the value from Run 2, both at the applicable reference
label: BODY

text: temperature, when entering values in a standard deviation or range chart. Control
label: BODY

text: chart run values must both be from either before adjustment or after adjustment.
label: BODY

text: A minimum of 12 replicate measurements are required to establish initial process
label: BODY

text: limits and 25 to 30 points are required for reporting valid uncertainty values.
label: BODY

text: Plot the calculated check standard volume and verify it is within established
label: BODY

text: limits. A t-test may be incorporated to check the observed value against an
label: BODY

text: accepted value.
label: BODY

text: The mean of the calculated check standard values is used to evaluate bias and
label: BODY

text: drift over time and may be used to identify or signify problems with the volume
label: BODY

text: standard or changes in water quality.
label: BODY

text: January 2016
label: BODY

text: SOP 14
label: BODY

text: Page 15 of 19
label: BODY

text: Check standard observations are used to calculate the standard deviation of the
label: BODY

text: measurement process, sp.
label: BODY

text: Assignment of Uncertainties
label: BODY

text: The limits of expanded uncertainty, U, include estimates of the standard uncertainty of
label: BODY

text: the mass standards used, uc, plus the measurement process repeatability, sp, and the
label: BODY

text: additional items noted below and in the uncertainty budget table,  Table 3, at
label: BODY

text: approximately a 95 percent level of confidence. See SOP 29 for the complete standard
label: BODY

text: operating procedure for calculating the uncertainty.
label: BODY

text: The standard uncertainty for the standards, us, is obtained from the calibration
label: BODY

text: report. The combined standard uncertainty, uc,  is used and not the expanded
label: BODY

text: uncertainty, U, therefore the reported uncertainty for the standard will usually
label: BODY

text: need to be divided by the coverage factor k. Multiple mass standards are often
label: BODY

text: used, so see SOP 29 for treatment of dependencies and correlations.
label: BODY

text: Standard deviation of the measurement process from control chart performance
label: BODY

text: (See SOP No. 17 or 20.)
label: BODY

text: The value for sp is obtained from the control chart data for check standards when
label: BODY

text: a check standard is available using this procedure. It may also be estimated based
label: BODY

text: on replicate measurements over time. Replicate measurements over time may
label: BODY

text: provide a pooled standard deviation that may be used or the average range is used
label: BODY

text: to estimate the standard deviation per SOP 17 or 20. This standard deviation value
label: BODY

text: is a repeatability factor related to the precision of the weighings and the setting of
label: BODY

text: the meniscus when present, but does not include uncertainties associated with
label: BODY

text: errors in reading the meniscus (See GMP 3.)
label: BODY

text: Include uncertainties associated with the reading of the meniscus when one is
label: BODY

text: present. See GMP 3 for details.
label: BODY

text: Other standard uncertainties usually included at this calibration level include
label: BODY

text: uncertainties associated with water temperature measurements, thermometer
label: BODY

text: accuracy, calculation of air density, standard uncertainties associated with the
label: BODY

text: density of the mass standards, coefficients of expansion, viscosity or surface
label: BODY

text: effects on the volume of liquid clinging to vessel walls after draining, improper
label: BODY

text: observance of drainage times, and the lack of internal cleanliness.
label: BODY

text: Example components to be considered for an uncertainty budget table are shown
label: BODY

text: in Table 3. Multiple values may need to be considered in some cases.
label: BODY

text: Appendix C
label: HH1

text: Test Notes for Large Provers
label: BODY

text: Pour and drain times.
label: BODY

text: It is impractical to completely drain a filled container, because some of the contents will
label: BODY

text: remain as a film. By strict adherence to a specified procedure, the residual contents can
label: BODY

text: be held essentially constant so that, reproducible calibration constants can be obtained.
label: BODY

text: The conventionally selected conditions are as follows:
label: BODY

text: For bottom-drain containers: open drain valve fully and allow contents to
label: BODY

text: discharge at maximum rate. When flow ceases, wait 30 s, close valve, and touch
label: BODY

text: off any drops adhering to spout.
label: BODY

text: For pour-type containers: pour contents by gradually tilting container to an 85º
label: BODY

text: angle, so that virtually all liquid is delivered in 30 s. Allow to drain for an
label: BODY

text: additional 10 s, then touch off any drops adhering to the lip.
label: BODY

text: The instructions described above must be precisely followed during calibration and use
label: BODY

text: of the calibrated vessels.
label: BODY

text: Evaporation losses.
label: BODY

text: A suitable cap should be placed on the top of open vessels to minimize evaporation
label: BODY

text: losses. If used, the cap must be included in all weighings.
label: BODY

text: Slicker-plate.
label: BODY

text: When a slicker-plate standard is calibrated, the plate should be used to fix the water level
label: BODY

text: in it. A transfer vessel is recommended for use when calibrating a slicker-plate type
label: BODY

text: standard. But if the standard is weighed, the plate must be weighed with the standard
label: BODY

text: during each such operation.
label: BODY
